data.title: search or files exclude isn't working anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-insider
- OS Version: W10 15063.608

one of the exclude settings aren't working anymore. vscode is sitting here scanning my entire production image upload directory causing the remote mount to choke to hell lol. these settings WERE working for a long time. but maybe two weeks or so now its been bad.

settings i have been using. i called them the "fknn staaaap" settings punching sshfs in the face.

```
	"search.exclude": {
		"**/.git": true,
		"**/www/media": true,
		"**/www/media/*": true,
		"**/www/media-live": true,
		"**/www/media-live/*": true,
		"**/vendor": true
	},
	"files.exclude": {
		"**/.git": true,
		"**/www/media": true,
		"**/www/media/*": true,
		"**/www/media-live": true,
		"**/www/media-live/*": true
	},
	"files.watcherExclude": {
		"**/.git": true,
		"**/www/media": true,
		"**/www/media/*": true,
		"**/www/media-live": true,
		"**/www/media-live/*": true,
		"**/vendor": true,
		"**/": true
	},
```
screenshot of my filesystem log where code is scanning everything.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/881944/30671263-8fca981e-9e2b-11e7-9716-8704b4eb71c2.png)

scrolls for evrrrrrrrr, tens of thousands of uploads in there rofl.

it will eventually lag vscode out so hard trying to do this over the remote mount that i cant save anything and even opening a new terminal will give up for some reason, which i would have expected to be unrelated.

i know its code because it starts flooding the log the moment i launch it and stops the moment i quit. additionally, eventually, code will start spamming me with ERROR banners at the top of the window for these files also in that log, because it has choked my mount, once it eventually times out trying to read them i guess.

Steps to Reproduce:

2. Switch to another doc and the back.

Bug: The occurrence highlight disappears. Ideally, it should remain, like it does with Visual Studio 2017.

data.title: Display unique directory label for quickopen files
data.body:
In multi-root workspaces, the quickopen shows the relative directory path, including the workspace folder basename, as the label for file results in order to disambiguate files from different workspace folders:

![selection_016](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1646931/30669152-0c5b8c0e-9e12-11e7-959b-53eac94724fa.png)

In cases such as the one shown above, 2 or more workspace folders may share the same basename ("mux" in this case). Such cases arise commonly when you've checked out a fork of another repository or you've checked out a different revision into a separate working tree.

In these cases, including the directory up to the workspace folder basename is no longer sufficient to disambiguate the results (as shown above). Using the absolute path would satisfy uniqueness, but the absolute path is often too long and hard to visually distinguish, especially if the first few path components are the same. Ideally, the directory label should include just enough parent components to disambiguate a file among all workspace folders. For instance:

![selection_017](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1646931/30669303-b009cbea-9e12-11e7-8431-a437a60a499a.png)

In cases where the workspace folder basename is unique, the old behavior should remain (displaying basename plus the relative path from the workspace folder root).

If there's agreement this would be useful, I can open a PR from https://github.com/beyang/vscode, which implements this change.

data.title: Poor resize performance for editor with many code lenses
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:24:39.530Z) and 1.17.0-insider f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: Extensions are disabled
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make sure code lenses are enabled:

```json
"editor.codeLens": true,
"typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled": true,
```

2. Open a file that will have many code lenses, such as this `d.ts` file
[tsserverlibrary.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1319319/tsserverlibrary.txt)

3. Try resizing the editor

**Bug**

![sep-20-2017 14-36-16](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12821956/30668898-290292f4-9e11-11e7-8a55-6c8ed7e5be13.gif)


I don't see any additional calls being made to TS to compute the code lenses.

data.title: Display line number as hybrid styles

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I believe there is currently no option to display both absolute and relative line numbers. Available options for vscode are: 'on', 'off', and 'relative'.

The relative shows the relative line numbers for all lines except the current line. The current line is displayed as absolute number.

![vscode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31377202/30665564-05f0bbd2-9e17-11e7-9b37-770ef39fd0a7.png)

It would be nice, however, if we could have both absolute lines and relative lines displayed simultaneously. Here are two examples:

![vs](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31377202/30665590-19191e2a-9e17-11e7-9689-d03460126959.png)

![extension](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31377202/30665581-12cc620c-9e17-11e7-89d8-965a1682c14d.png)

The above images are from an extension of Visual Studio and the deprecated extension [Relative Line Numbers](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=extr0py.vscode-relative-line-numbers). The extension is deprecated since VS Code 1.6 where the line number setting was officially supported.

In addition, some of additional features that would be great to have are:

1. to customise the colours of line numbers, preferably to different colours as shown in the 2nd image
1. to customise the positions of the two line numbers so we can choose to place absolute lines at left or right

Since this feature was already supported by an old extension, I imagine it would not be so hard to implement. Would it be possible to support Hybrid Line Number feature in VS Code?

data.title: "Start Without Debugging" doesn't work properly

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I've tried to use the `Start Without Debugging` action to run a dummy javascript file, but I've found some, maybe related, issues: 

- After executing it the statusbar changes color to `statusBar.debuggingBackground`, implying that a debugging session has started, then right after the file has been run the statusbar goes back to its previous color, implying that the debugging session has terminated, but not `onDidTerminateDebugSession` nor `onDidChangeActiveDebugSession` get triggered, which instead imply that the debugging session hasn't been terminated yet.
- Terminating a `Start Without Debugging` session triggers `onDidChangeActiveDebugSession` but not `onDidTerminateDebugSession`.

PS. the whole "**Debug** -> Start **Without Debugging**" doesn't sound right.

Version: 1.16.1
OS: macOS 10.13

data.title: [json] mark all duplicated keys

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When  you enter a duplicate key warning only shows you second key but often you need to compare it to the original:
![onedup](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/30662141-bc4847a6-9e4e-11e7-8509-ac6d57aea9be.png) ![onedupe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/30662158-caf6e3fc-9e4e-11e7-9f7c-9d4334646848.png)


But if you create 3 keys (1 original, 2 duplicates) you can quickly see 2nd and 3rd keys:

![twodup](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/30662277-361d4982-9e4f-11e7-8046-a737eb5869d5.png) ![twodupe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/30662291-417ef302-9e4f-11e7-9957-c90823e2e840.png)



More importantly you can now *fast travel* to 2nd and 3rd with problems view:

![problemsview](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638156/30662398-993d3478-9e4f-11e7-82a3-680da0ceb86b.png)


Or by hotkeys:


F8 | Go to Next Error or Warning | editor.action.marker.next
-- | -- | --
Shift+F8 | Go to Previous Error or Warning | editor.action.marker.prev

data.title: workspaceContains starts a search over full workspace, including .git/, node_modules/
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/34487 made one improvement by batching workspaceContains searches.

Keeping this one open to consider excluding .git and node_modules in a smart way, which could give a huge improvement.

cc @jrieken @alexandrudima 

>>> We should include the exclude settings, or hardcode an exclusion to a few folders.
>>
>> So, how do you then active on .git/HEAD?
>
> Maybe add some smartness to search .git/ or node_modules/ if it's explicitly mentioned in the workspaceContains: search glob?

data.title: editor.fold command will fold the enclosing block but editor.foldRecursively will not

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (b0c0634339c6f64a5c7f08b56fe732fb9154d3c4, 2017-09-15T05:24:23.107Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0
vsc-material-theme|Equ|1.0.2
Lua|key|0.0.9
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4

(2 theme extensions excluded)


---

When my cursor is on a line of code that is not the first line of a foldable block (i.e. it's somewhere in the middle of the block) some folding commands will work while other will not. Specifically, editor.fold will cause the enclosing block to fold, while editor.foldRecursively does nothing at all.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Place your cursor on a line that is within a foldable block, but not on the first line of the foldable block
2. Trigger the editor.fold command
3. Notice the block folds
4. Re-expand the block and return your cursor to the same position within the block
5. trigger the editor.foldRecursively command
6. Notice nothing happens

Example of step 1
![fold bug 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/484784/30654830-c1ee9976-9df4-11e7-8843-bec4463ff6cd.png)

Expected behavior of step 5
![fold bug 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/484784/30654831-c1f6cda8-9df4-11e7-965c-64918c60d5d7.png)

data.title: Allow user to create Tasks with the Windows 'Jump List' functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
No matter how many projects and workspaces I've had open, my Tasks entries are always blank.

![2017-09-20 16_57_48-clipboard](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23440/30654176-134bc0ac-9e25-11e7-8e30-e0eac6459687.png)

I've tried dragging folders to them but it doesn't work (I get a 'not allowed' cursor icon). So it seems as if this functionality is redundant.

Further, in Code itself, there appears to be no mechanism for saving the current workspace as a 'Task' in the taskbar for easy retrieval later. This would be especially useful for me as it could then be used to maintain a state for disparate files that aren't connected to a single workspace.

This functionality would probably also be useful for users who are used to the Notepad++ way of managing sessions - something which Code doesn't seem to support or allow (hotExit doesn't work with unsaved documents).

data.title: Test: explorer actions and labels
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/34229 https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/34218

- [x] Win @mjbvz 
- [x] Mac @seanmcbreen 
- [x] Linux @sandy081 

Complexity: 3

We have refactored the explorer to now support remote file systems. Note that there is a seperate test plan item for remote files. For local files verify the following works as before, both for single folder and multi folder workbench:
* file labels are shown properly (hover, tab area, title are when tabs are swtiched off)
* all the context menu actions work properly in explorer and open editors view
* drag and drop (both inside vscode, and droping a resource from outside of vscode)
* title menu actions in explorer and keyboard actions (rename, delete) work properly
* randomly pick some file actions from the command palette and verify they work

data.title: Introduce IRelativePattern and adopt in DocumentFilter/FileWatcher/FileSearch
[Feature Request] Different way to complete with tab (YCM style)
data.body:
## Before I start
Hello.

VS Code is great software, and i really like how it grows over time, so I want to improve the experience of using it.

Previously I used Vim a lot, because at work it is my only option, but at home for hobbies I use VS Code, and when I program in C, at my work I use YouCompleteMe (YCM) plugin for `tab` completions, and I really like the way it works. 

## Touch typing

The main thing is that I use all my 10 fingers to write code, and rarelly move hands from home row, because vim, _you know_, has `hjkl` and other ways to navigate in code. So first thing was to install vim-extension to VS Code, to stop using arrow keys, and it works well. But tab completion still forces me to use arrows.

How it works in Vim: I select from the list using the `tab` button and I confirm the completion by simply continuing typing. Therefore, my hands never leave the home row.

The way it works in VS Code: `tab` button completes the completion and closes popup, And arrow keys are just navigate within the list and not confirm anything. So I need to navigate in list with arrow keys (and leave home row) then press `tab` for completion. In fact it is way faster just to type most things by hand just looking at the popup for reference. And it is frustrating after long way of programming in vim.

## So what do _you_ want?
All I want is an option in settings to change `tab` key behavior to something like (or close to) YCM style. 
The behavior itself can be described like so:
  1. Start typing (`std::` for example)
  2. Completion popup is displayed (or invoked by `tab`)
  3. Press the `tab` and completion is done, but popup isn't closed
  4. Press tab again, and next item in popup list replaces previous completion
  5. Press tab until you will be satisfied with your completed text
  6. Continue typing, popup is closed (unless you folow the completion hint from popup)

That's how (mostly) it works in such plugins like YouCompleteMe, Supertab in Vim. You can try this plugins for better understanding of what i mean. And it is comfortable because you don't need arrow keys at all.

## P.S:
Previously (before Vim) I used Visual Studio for C++ programming, and when I swithced to YCM's completion system I noticed a great boost of writing speed. YCM has it's own plugin in the marketplace, but it uses standard `tab` behavior, which makes it little less useful an makes me little less productive.

Thanks.
